subject: Fashion
title: Pockets and the Gender Gap
description: One-minute skill: Pockets and the Gender Gap.

hook.text: The average men's jeans pocket is 24 cm deep. Women's? Just 13 cm. Some are sewn shut entirely.

buildup.text: In the 1800s, women carried belongings in 'pockets' tied under their skirts, hidden from view.

discovery.text: When slim silhouettes became fashionable, pockets were removed so they wouldn't ruin the line.

twist.text: The handbag industry exploded to fill the gap. Women paid extra to carry what men got for free.

climax.text: The pocket gap isn't an accident. It's a design choice that created a multi-billion-dollar industry.

punchline.text: Men got pockets. Women got a handbag industry.

quiz.question: Why were pockets largely removed from women's clothing?
options: Women's rights groups demanded they be replaced with purses
Fabric rationing during wartime forced designers to cut pockets
Slim fashion silhouettes meant pockets disrupted the garment line
